title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 20 october [1867]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 20 October [1867]
text: Brooklyn 1867OctoOctober20thwell Walterit is sundaySunday and no word nor letter have i got yet i am very confidantconfident you have sent my accustomed letter and it has been taken it makes me feel almost sick i wanted to hear from you what you thought of the proposition of the portland avePortland Avenue property and i wanted to hear from you any how it seems like six months since i got a letter i spoke to the letter carrier on fridayFriday he would hardly stop long enoughfenough for me to say any thing to him) all he said itsit's none of my fault itsit's none of my fault in A quick way and hurried on you have undoubtablyundoubtedly got the letter i sent on thursdayThursday last and the one i wrote the wensdayWednesday i got your last the 9th when it didentdidn't come last wednsdayWednesday i was fearfullfearful something was wrong but as i sometimes didentdidn't get it till thursdayThursday i thought i would wait but now i have no hopes of it george wants very much to know what you think of the plan of the shop smith dontdon't care so much to sell it now he saissays this nisenice of property he thinks will pay to keep it but he will sell it but aintain't so anxious too as he was) martha and the children are well marthe is very discontendeddiscontented she wants Jeff to come and she dontdon't want him to come as she aintain't ready to go yet she is going to hire a sewing machine Â½ month and she said if i would get one or two common gowns she would stichstitch them for me and i was going to get one out of my remittance last week but got disappointed) i am about the same walter dear as i was when you was here the medicine dontdon't seem to benefit me much yet but i take it yet it is very warm here) helen and emma price was here the other day to dinner) i would write more walter but i cantcan't this time good bie walter deari was glad your peicepiece was done Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 20 October [1867]
